content: Looks like a corrupt prefs.js file which has been renamed in prefs-x.js and replaced by a virgin prefs.js file (about 6 to 7kB size). In TB go to menu Help > Troubleshooting Information > Profile Folder > Open Folder... then quit TB. In the profile folder look for any prefs.js or prefs-x.js files and report them with their names and their sizes

content:
Bucko said
Found an 6 kb pref.js and a 82 kb prefs-1.js file.

The 6 kb file is the "virgin" prefs.js file TB created when it considered the 82 kb file corrupted and renamed it in prefs-1. js file

If you have a backup copy of your profile folder , copy the prefs.js file from there and - TB closed - paste it in your actual profile folder and restart TB. Most times people have no backup of their data. If this is true for you we'll play "double or nothing": Open the TB profile folder, quit TB, delete the 6 kB prefs.js, simply rename the big prefs-1.js file in prefs.js and restart TB. This is a bet, most people loose it but I have seen some examples that the prefs.js file that TB had renamed was not corrupt.

If this doesn't work you'll have to recreate all your accounts. If you have IMAP your messages will be back as soon as TB synchronises with the server. If you use POP there will be some accessory labour to be done
creator: Mapenzi

Essentially the Verizon system for mail is one large mess. Largely i think because AOL are not really managing anything it is Yahoo now and as they are owned by bankers it is not really a technology company.

There is no setting option for OAUTH. The one account that isn't working had the password changed 11 days ago, along with the other two verizon.net accounts. All three worked until 10/15, when one of the three now throws an error, but doesn't' ask for the password (as you indicate above.)

For the one non-working account, I changed the 3rd party password on the web page login, which usually works to correct the problem with the Thunderbird send and receive issue. But, not this time. It still will not send messages, saying: Sending of the message failed. An error occurred while sending mail. The mail server responded: Email rejected. Please verify that your email address is correct in your account settings and try again.

Of course, nothing has changed in my account settings from when the account could send outgoing messages just a few days ago. The account still receives messages with no problem, so I can't see how the settings in the account could be incorrect.

One thing I did was to go through the settings and remove any upper-case letters I had for readability. They have been this way for years, but I though, what the heck, lets do something. This edit was seen as a "change" in the user name on the account, and Thunderbird requested a restart. After the restart, the next email I sent requested the manual password entry which I recently updated (30 min ago). The system took the password and sent the message.

Lets hope the system will run without a glitch for more than 11 days.  :=D


Thanks for your help Matt !!

content:
You are more than welcome to rewrite the article and bring it up to date. I don't have the time or the inclination any longer.

I have no idea what you are talking about with contact and labels. Do Google contact have labels? Apparently they are used for creating mailing lists. I can use Google search. They certainly do not appear in Thunderbird as a mailing list as I just added a label to someone in my gmail contact and no mailing list with a single entry appearing in that address book locally after I syncronised the address book. But that does not suprise me as the contact sync is implemented with carddav which is based on the vcard standard. Vcards do not have mailing lists as a part of their description I do not think.

It appears the tbsync add-on does do something with groups using the Google people API . See https://github.com/zanonmark/Google-4-TbSync#current-status-and-roadmap--known-limitations

The calendar addon provider for google calendar offers tasks. Those are not included in the caldav standard and therefore are not included in the native calendar synchronization.
creator: MattAuSupport

What I need is to be able to categorize my contacts, e.g. by church, family, personal, professional etc. Outlook calls these Categories. Google calls them Labels. Some other platforms call them tags. I don't care what they're called, as long as they can be ported across platforms. Outlook tries to store its categories in Google's data structure, but often fails. content: I suppose you're talking about the Primary Password. The Primary Password protects the account password(s) of the email accounts you set up in Thunderbird. It does not protect the contents of the Thunderbird profile. Also see https://support.mozilla.org/kb/protect-your-thunderbird-passwords-primary-password
creator: christ1

content: thank you, im still trying to understand how it works
creator: brew

content: It is as @Christ1 explained: it only protects the account passwords. So, another person may see messages on the PC that have been downloaded, but cannot send or retrieve mail. For account security, you need to pursue at a higher level, such as with a Windows password. This does not provide the security you want.

content: First, make sure you have all the messages. clicking File>offline>download should do that Then, a clean way is this: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - EXIT thunderbird now - you are now in windows file explorer - your account is at imapmail\<IMAPaccount> messages are there, such as input, input.msf, sent, sent.msf - the Local Folders folder is at Mail\Local Folders - Click to the Imapmail\<imapaccount? folder in that folder and COPY the folders other than the msf entries and paste into the Mail\Local Folders folder. - restart thunderbird and the messages should be there </p>

content:
Hello

Apparently, the information (among other) is in the file, xulstore.json, in the profile folder.

You can try.

1 - Go to your profil folder https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_how-do-i-find-my-profile 2 - Stop Thunderbird 3 - Delete the file xulstore.json (or rename it, for example, to xulstore.json-old) 4 - Start Thunderbird 5 - Perform your tests

A new xulstore.json file will be created. And, please check, xulstore.json -> right-click on it and select Properties -> Attributes -> the read-only box uncheck.

content: What mail provider are you using. 2FA is not something Thunderbird inherently supports. Thunderbird connects to the mail server often many times a minute, hence suggestions that you use app passwords and oauh authentication, but it depends on the provider as to what is the best approach.
creator: MattAuSupport

creator: brew

content:
For outlook.com Thunderbird will set itself up using oauth authentication, Microsoft's preferred authentication method, they refer to it a "Modern Authentication" for the account. You will go through an initial set of web pages served by outlook.com or office365.com where your 2FA will be utilized. After that there will be a token issued to Thunbird to use to connect you and your mail based on the permissions granted in the web page flow.

2FA is NOT an option for outlook.com.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Hi mrapol,

For us to better investigate this issue, we will need some more information.

Could you please do the following?

  1. Open the menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information, then click Copy text to Clipboard.
  2. Go to https://pastebin.mozilla.org/, paste the clipboard by right clicking in the large text area, select paste from the menu, change the retention period to expire in 28 days, use the Paste Snippet button to create a page containing your info, then copy the resulting URL (address) of the page created.
  3. Open a reply to this post, and paste the URL to your troubleshooting information you just copied.
  4. Please also provide results for the following test on your system
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected in Thunderbird troubleshooting mode?
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected with your OS started in safe mode with Networking. Instructions for each operating system: Windows 10/11, Windows 8, Windows 7, OSX
creator: moz_fan

content:
when Thunderbird closes it updates a file called prefs.js with the changes made in this session. This is especiall7y so for new accounts added. Unfortunately I have been seeing a rash of antivirus programs blocking the writing of this file, so when you look in the actual profile folder there is sometimes hundreds of copies, neatly numbered in sequence and then ignored.

SO open your profile folder in file manger. The troubleshooting information on the help menu has a link in it. and check how many prefs.js files you have stored there and the dates.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: If your Android contacts are Google Contacts and the calendar is also Google, both can be synced with TB. ≡ - New Account - Calendar - On the Network, ≡ - New Account - New Address Book - CardDAV Address Book.

creator: ANobodyFromSomewhere@gmail.com

content: POP accounts have few folders when set up, usually input and trash, with sent added when first message is sent. If your account had hundreds of folders and was a POP account, they were either deleted when you deleted the account, or they are somewhere in your profiles folder. You can search there with these steps: - click help>troubleshootinginformaition - scroll to 'profiles' and click 'about:profiles' - the new screen lists all profile folders, click the OPEN button and then click the Mail folder, and then click through each POP comcast account to see if one of them has the lost folders If you find them, post back for steps to recover them.
creator: davidsk

Based on the screenshot you have sent, the mail is not marked as junk by Thunderbird, if it was, the flame symbol would be red. Also, by default the built-in spam classifier does not move the messages to folders, especially not to a custom one.
